canonical_explanation.text: In the human body, the circulatory system transports substances to all parts. Blood is a fluid connective tissue consisting of plasma (liquid part), red blood cells (RBCs containing haemoglobin for carrying oxygen), white blood cells (WBCs for fighting infections), and platelets (for blood clotting). Blood flows through blood vessels: arteries carry oxygenated blood away from the heart, veins carry deoxygenated blood towards the heart, and capillaries are thin-walled vessels where exchange of substances occurs. The heart is a muscular organ with four chambers (two atria and two ventricles) that pumps blood throughout the body. The heartbeat can be felt as a pulse, and a stethoscope is used to hear it. The normal heart rate is about 72 beats per minute. The excretory system removes waste products: kidneys filter blood to produce urine, which passes through ureters to the urinary bladder and is expelled through the urethra. Dialysis is the artificial filtering of blood when kidneys fail. In plants, xylem transports water and minerals from roots to leaves, while phloem transports food from leaves to other parts. Transpiration (loss of water from leaf stomata) creates a suction force that helps pull water upward.
rules: Blood consists of plasma, RBCs (carry oxygen using haemoglobin), WBCs (fight infection), and platelets (clotting).
Arteries carry oxygenated blood away from heart; veins carry deoxygenated blood to heart.
Capillaries are thin-walled blood vessels where exchange of substances occurs.
Heart has four chambers: two atria (upper) and two ventricles (lower).
Normal heart rate is about 72 beats per minute; stethoscope amplifies heartbeat.
Kidneys filter blood to remove waste (urea) and excess water as urine.
Dialysis is used to filter blood artificially when kidneys fail.
Xylem transports water and minerals from roots upward in plants.
Phloem transports prepared food from leaves to other parts of the plant.
Transpiration creates a suction pull that helps transport water upward in plants.

questions.question_text: Blood is classified as a:
questions.explanation_correct: Blood is classified as a fluid connective tissue. It connects different parts of the body by transporting substances like oxygen, nutrients, hormones, and waste products between them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Blood is not a muscle tissue (A), epithelial tissue (C), or nervous tissue (D). It is a fluid connective tissue (B) because it flows through the body connecting all organs by transporting substances.

questions.question_text: The red colour of blood is due to a pigment called:
questions.explanation_correct: Haemoglobin is the red pigment present in red blood cells (RBCs). It contains iron and gives blood its red colour. Haemoglobin binds with oxygen and transports it to all cells in the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chlorophyll (A) is the green pigment in plants. Melanin (B) is the skin pigment. Carotene (D) is an orange pigment. Haemoglobin (C) gives blood its red colour.

questions.question_text: Which component of blood helps in fighting infections?
questions.explanation_correct: White blood cells (WBCs or leucocytes) fight infections and diseases. They identify and destroy harmful bacteria, viruses, and other pathogens that enter the body, acting as the body's defence system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Red blood cells (A) carry oxygen. Platelets (B) help in blood clotting. Plasma (C) is the liquid part that transports nutrients. White blood cells (D) fight infections.

questions.question_text: Which component of blood helps in clotting when you get a cut?
questions.explanation_correct: Platelets (thrombocytes) help in blood clotting. When you get a cut, platelets gather at the wound site and form a clot (scab) that seals the wound and prevents excessive blood loss.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Red blood cells (A) transport oxygen. White blood cells (B) fight infections. Plasma (D) is the liquid carrier. Platelets (C) are responsible for blood clotting at wound sites.

questions.question_text: Blood vessels that carry blood away from the heart are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Arteries are blood vessels that carry blood away from the heart to various parts of the body. They have thick, elastic walls to withstand the high pressure of blood pumped by the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Veins (A) carry blood towards the heart. Capillaries (B) are thin vessels for exchange. Nerves (D) carry nerve signals, not blood. Arteries (C) carry blood away from the heart.

questions.question_text: Blood vessels that carry blood back to the heart are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Veins carry blood from various body parts back to the heart. They have thinner walls than arteries and contain valves that prevent the backward flow of blood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Arteries (A) carry blood away from the heart. Capillaries (C) are for exchange at the tissue level. Bronchi (D) are part of the respiratory system. Veins (B) carry blood towards the heart.

questions.question_text: Capillaries have very thin walls because:

options.text: They need to be strong to handle high pressure
They allow easy exchange of substances between blood and body tissues
They need to carry blood at high speed
They are too small to have thick walls

questions.explanation_correct: Capillaries have walls that are only one cell thick. This allows easy exchange of oxygen, nutrients, carbon dioxide, and waste products between the blood and the surrounding body tissues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Capillaries have low pressure (A). They do not carry blood at high speed (C). Their thin walls are not simply due to small size (D). The thin walls facilitate exchange of substances (B) with tissues.

questions.question_text: The human heart has how many chambers?
questions.explanation_correct: The human heart has four chambers: two upper chambers called atria (right atrium and left atrium) and two lower chambers called ventricles (right ventricle and left ventricle).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fish have two chambers (A). Amphibians have three (B). There is no five-chambered heart (D). The human heart has four chambers (C): two atria and two ventricles.

questions.question_text: A doctor uses a ___ to listen to the heartbeat.
questions.explanation_correct: A stethoscope is a medical instrument used by doctors to listen to the heartbeat and other internal body sounds like breathing. It amplifies the sound of the heart beating.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A thermometer (A) measures temperature. A microscope (C) magnifies small objects. A barometer (D) measures atmospheric pressure. A stethoscope (B) is used to hear the heartbeat.

questions.question_text: The normal resting heart rate of an adult human is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The normal resting heart rate of a healthy adult is approximately 72 beats per minute. This can vary slightly between individuals but generally falls in the range of 60-100 beats per minute.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 30-40 (A) is too slow (bradycardia). 120-150 (C) and 200 (D) are too fast and occur during intense exercise. The normal resting heart rate is about 72 beats per minute (B).

questions.question_text: You can feel your pulse by pressing your wrist because:

options.text: A vein passes close to the surface at the wrist
An artery passes close to the surface and expands with each heartbeat
A nerve is close to the surface at the wrist
The bones at the wrist vibrate with each heartbeat

questions.explanation_correct: The pulse is felt because an artery (radial artery) passes close to the skin surface at the wrist. Each time the heart beats, blood is pumped through the artery, causing it to expand briefly, which you can feel as a pulse.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Veins (A) have low pressure and do not produce a noticeable pulse. Nerves (C) and bones (D) do not expand with heartbeats. Arteries (B) expand with each heartbeat, creating the pulse.

questions.question_text: The main organs of the human excretory system are the:
questions.explanation_correct: The kidneys are the main excretory organs. They filter blood to remove waste products (mainly urea), excess water, and salts, forming urine. Humans have two kidneys, one on each side of the spine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lungs (A) remove CO2 but are part of the respiratory system. The stomach (C) digests food. The liver (D) produces urea but kidneys filter it out. Kidneys (B) are the main excretory organs.

questions.question_text: The waste product filtered by the kidneys from the blood is mainly:
questions.explanation_correct: Urea is the main nitrogenous waste product filtered by the kidneys. It is produced in the liver from the breakdown of excess amino acids and is dissolved in water to form urine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CO2 (A) is removed by the lungs. Oxygen (C) is used by cells, not filtered out. Glucose (D) is a nutrient, not a waste product. Urea (B) is the primary waste filtered by kidneys.

questions.question_text: Urine is stored temporarily in the body in the:
questions.explanation_correct: The urinary bladder is a muscular bag-like structure that temporarily stores urine produced by the kidneys. When the bladder is full, we feel the urge to urinate, and urine is expelled through the urethra.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kidneys (A) produce urine. Ureters (B) are tubes that transport urine from kidneys to bladder. The urethra (D) expels urine. The urinary bladder (C) stores urine temporarily.

questions.question_text: When kidneys fail to function properly, blood is filtered artificially by a process called:
questions.explanation_correct: Dialysis is the process of artificially filtering blood using a machine when the kidneys fail. The blood is passed through a dialysis machine that removes waste products and excess water, just like healthy kidneys would.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Transfusion (A) is transferring blood. Transplant (C) is replacing a failed organ. Digestion (D) breaks down food. Dialysis (B) is the artificial filtration of blood when kidneys fail.

questions.question_text: In plants, water and minerals are transported from roots to leaves through:
questions.explanation_correct: Xylem is the vascular tissue in plants that transports water and dissolved minerals from the roots upward to the stems, branches, and leaves. It forms a continuous network of tubes throughout the plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Phloem (A) transports food, not water. Stomata (C) are pores for gas exchange. Root hairs (D) absorb water from soil. Xylem (B) is the tissue that transports water and minerals upward.

questions.question_text: Prepared food (sugars) in plants is transported from leaves to other parts through:
questions.explanation_correct: Phloem is the vascular tissue that transports prepared food (mainly sugars made during photosynthesis) from the leaves to all other parts of the plant, including roots, stems, fruits, and flowers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Xylem (A) transports water and minerals. Root hairs (C) absorb water. Guard cells (D) control stomata. Phloem (B) transports prepared food throughout the plant.

questions.question_text: The loss of water from the surface of leaves in the form of water vapour is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Transpiration is the loss of water vapour from the surface of leaves, mainly through stomata. It creates a suction force (transpiration pull) that helps draw water upward from roots through the xylem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Absorption (A) is taking in water by roots. Evaporation (B) is a general term for liquid to gas change. Respiration (D) is energy release from food. Transpiration (C) is the specific loss of water from leaves.

questions.question_text: A person living at high altitude would have more red blood cells than someone at sea level. This is because:

options.text: There is more food available at high altitude
There is less oxygen at high altitude, so more RBCs are needed to carry oxygen
It is colder at high altitude
There is more sunlight at high altitude

questions.explanation_correct: At high altitudes, the air contains less oxygen. The body produces more red blood cells (which contain haemoglobin) to compensate, ensuring enough oxygen is captured and delivered to all cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Food (A), temperature (C), and sunlight (D) are not the primary reasons. The lower oxygen levels at high altitude (B) trigger the body to produce more RBCs for better oxygen transport.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes arteries?

options.text: Thin-walled vessels with valves that carry deoxygenated blood
Thick-walled elastic vessels without valves that carry blood at high pressure
Single-cell thick vessels for exchange of materials
Vessels that only carry blood to the kidneys

questions.explanation_correct: Arteries have thick, elastic muscular walls to withstand the high pressure of blood pumped by the heart. They generally do not have valves (unlike veins) and carry blood at high pressure away from the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thin-walled with valves (A) describes veins. Single-cell thick (C) describes capillaries. Arteries go to all organs (D). Arteries have thick, elastic walls without valves (B).

questions.question_text:
Match the blood component with its function:
(i) Plasma - (a) Carries oxygen
(ii) RBC - (b) Blood clotting
(iii) WBC - (c) Transports dissolved substances
(iv) Platelets - (d) Fights infection
questions.explanation_correct: Plasma transports dissolved substances like nutrients and hormones (c). RBCs carry oxygen using haemoglobin (a). WBCs fight infections (d). Platelets help in blood clotting (b). Option A is correct.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plasma carries dissolved substances, RBCs carry oxygen, WBCs fight infection, and platelets clot blood. Only option A correctly matches all four components with their functions.

questions.question_text: A plant is placed with its stem in coloured (red) water. After a few hours, the colour will be seen in the:
questions.explanation_correct: The coloured water is absorbed and transported upward through the xylem vessels. It reaches the leaves and petals, making them appear red. This experiment demonstrates the transport of water through xylem in plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The colour moves upward through xylem, not to roots (A), soil (C), or air (D). The coloured water will be visible in leaves and petals (B) as it travels through xylem vessels.

questions.question_text: Transpiration helps plants by:

options.text: Creating a suction pull that draws water upward from roots

questions.explanation_correct: Transpiration creates a suction force (transpiration pull) that helps draw water and minerals from the roots upward through the xylem to the leaves. It also helps cool the plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Transpiration does not provide food (A), produce oxygen (C), or fix nitrogen (D). Its key role is creating a suction pull (B) that drives water transport from roots to leaves.

questions.question_text: The correct path of urine from formation to excretion is:
questions.explanation_correct: Urine is formed in the kidneys, travels through the ureters (tubes connecting kidneys to bladder), is stored in the urinary bladder, and is finally expelled from the body through the urethra.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The urethra cannot come before the bladder (A). Kidneys come first (C is wrong). Ureters connect kidneys to bladder (D is wrong). The correct path is B: Kidney -> Ureter -> Bladder -> Urethra.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Arteries have thicker walls than veins.
Reason: Arteries carry blood at high pressure pumped by the heart.
Choose the correct option:

options.text: Both are true and the reason correctly explains the assertion
Both are true but reason does not explain assertion
Assertion is true but reason is false

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are true. Arteries have thick, elastic walls specifically because they must withstand the high pressure of blood being pumped directly from the heart. The reason correctly explains why arteries are thick-walled.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Arteries are indeed thicker than veins, and this is directly because of the high blood pressure they carry. Both statements are true and connected (A).

questions.question_text: Veins have valves that prevent the backward flow of blood. This is necessary because:

options.text: Blood in veins flows at very high pressure
Blood in veins flows at low pressure and could flow backward due to gravity

questions.explanation_correct: Veins carry blood at low pressure (since they are far from the heart). Valves prevent backward flow that could occur due to gravity, especially in the legs where blood must travel upward against gravity to reach the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Veins have low pressure, not high (A). Veins mostly carry deoxygenated blood (C). Valves prevent backflow, not pump blood (D). Low pressure and gravity necessitate valves (B).

questions.question_text: A person suffering from kidney failure needs regular dialysis. During dialysis, the blood is:

options.text: Passed through a machine that filters out waste products
Mixed with medicine to remove toxins

questions.explanation_correct: During dialysis, the patient's blood is drawn out and passed through a dialysis machine (artificial kidney) that filters out waste products like urea and excess water, mimicking the function of healthy kidneys.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Blood is not replaced (A), heated (C), or simply mixed with medicine (D). It is passed through a filtering machine (B) that removes waste products that the failed kidneys cannot remove.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about xylem and phloem is INCORRECT?

options.text: Xylem transports water and minerals upward
Both xylem and phloem transport water
Xylem and phloem together form the vascular system of plants

questions.explanation_correct: The statement that both transport water is incorrect. Only xylem transports water and minerals. Phloem transports prepared food (sugars). They have distinct and separate functions in the plant's vascular system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Xylem does transport water (A). Phloem does transport food (B). Together they form the vascular system (D). But only xylem (not both) transports water (C is incorrect).

questions.question_text: Which component of blood makes up the largest proportion by volume?
questions.explanation_correct: Plasma makes up about 55% of the total blood volume. It is the yellowish liquid part of blood in which blood cells, platelets, nutrients, hormones, and waste products are suspended and transported.
questions.explanation_incorrect: RBCs (A) make up about 45% of blood volume. WBCs (B) and platelets (C) make up less than 1%. Plasma (D) is the largest component at about 55% of total blood volume.

questions.question_text: After running, your heart beats faster because:

options.text: The heart needs to cool down
Muscles need more oxygen and nutrients, so blood must circulate faster
The heart gets tired from running
The lungs push the heart to beat faster

questions.explanation_correct: During exercise, muscles need more oxygen and nutrients for energy production and more CO2 needs to be removed. The heart beats faster to pump blood more quickly to meet these increased demands.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The heart does not need cooling (A) or get tired from running (C). Lungs do not push the heart (D). The heart beats faster to increase blood flow for higher oxygen and nutrient delivery (B).

questions.question_text: Arteries always carry oxygenated blood and veins always carry deoxygenated blood.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. While most arteries carry oxygenated blood, the pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs. Similarly, the pulmonary vein carries oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are exceptions. The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood to the lungs, and the pulmonary vein carries oxygenated blood back. So arteries and veins are defined by direction of flow (away from or to heart), not by oxygen content.

questions.question_text: Haemoglobin in red blood cells helps transport oxygen throughout the body.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Haemoglobin is an iron-containing protein in red blood cells that binds with oxygen in the lungs and carries it to all body cells. It is the reason blood appears red.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Haemoglobin binds with oxygen in the lungs, forming oxyhaemoglobin, and releases it at the tissues where oxygen is needed.

questions.question_text: Sweat produced by sweat glands also helps in excretion by removing some waste products.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Sweat contains water, salts, and small amounts of urea. Sweat glands help in excretion by removing these waste products from the body, in addition to helping regulate body temperature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sweat does contain waste products like urea and excess salts. While its primary function is temperature regulation, it also contributes to excretion.

questions.question_text: Phloem transports water and minerals from roots to leaves in plants.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Xylem (not phloem) transports water and minerals from roots to leaves. Phloem transports prepared food (sugars) from leaves to other parts of the plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement confuses xylem and phloem. Xylem transports water and minerals upward. Phloem transports prepared food from leaves to other plant parts.

questions.question_text: Transpiration has no role in the upward movement of water in plants.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Transpiration plays a crucial role in the upward movement of water. When water evaporates from leaf stomata during transpiration, it creates a suction pull (transpiration pull) that draws water upward through the xylem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Transpiration is actually very important for water transport. The transpiration pull it creates is one of the main forces driving the upward movement of water from roots to leaves.

questions.question_text: The upper chambers of the heart are called ventricles and the lower chambers are called atria.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. The upper chambers are called atria (singular: atrium) and the lower chambers are called ventricles. Atria receive blood entering the heart, while ventricles pump blood out of the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement reverses the names. The upper chambers are atria (which receive blood) and the lower chambers are ventricles (which pump blood out). The statement has them switched.

questions.question_text: Humans have two kidneys that are located on either side of the backbone.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Humans have two bean-shaped kidneys located on either side of the backbone (spine) in the abdominal cavity. Each kidney filters blood and produces urine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. The two kidneys are indeed located on either side of the backbone, one on the left and one on the right, in the lower abdominal area.

questions.question_text: The liquid part of blood in which blood cells are suspended is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Plasma is the yellowish liquid component of blood. It makes up about 55% of total blood volume and carries dissolved nutrients, hormones, waste products, and blood cells throughout the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'plasma'. It is the fluid matrix of blood in which RBCs, WBCs, platelets, nutrients, and other substances are dissolved or suspended.

questions.question_text: The vascular tissue that transports water and minerals from roots to leaves in plants is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Xylem is the vascular tissue responsible for transporting water and dissolved minerals from the roots upward to the stems, leaves, and other parts of the plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'xylem'. It forms a network of tubes running from roots to leaves, carrying water and minerals. Phloem, the other vascular tissue, transports food.

questions.question_text: The tubes that carry urine from the kidneys to the urinary bladder are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Ureters are thin muscular tubes that connect each kidney to the urinary bladder. They transport urine produced by the kidneys to the bladder where it is stored until excretion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'ureters'. These are the tubes connecting the kidneys to the urinary bladder, not to be confused with the urethra (which connects the bladder to the outside).

questions.question_text: The loss of water in the form of vapour from the leaves of plants is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Transpiration is the evaporation of water from the surface of plant leaves through stomata. It creates a transpiration pull that helps draw water upward through the xylem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'transpiration'. It is the process of water loss from leaves as vapour, which also creates the suction force needed for water transport from roots to leaves.

questions.question_text: A ___ is used by doctors to listen to the heartbeat of a patient.
questions.explanation_correct: A stethoscope is a medical instrument that amplifies the sound of the heartbeat. It has a chest piece that is placed on the patient's chest and tubes that carry the sound to the doctor's ears.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'stethoscope'. It is one of the most commonly used medical instruments for listening to heart sounds and checking heart health.

questions.question_text: The thin-walled blood vessels where exchange of gases and nutrients between blood and tissues occurs are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Capillaries are the thinnest blood vessels with walls only one cell thick. They connect arteries to veins and are the site where oxygen, nutrients, CO2, and waste products are exchanged between blood and body tissues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'capillaries'. Their extremely thin walls allow substances to pass through easily, making them the site of material exchange between blood and tissues.

questions.question_text: A person with fewer red blood cells than normal would most likely experience:

options.text: Tiredness and weakness due to reduced oxygen supply

questions.explanation_correct: Fewer RBCs means less haemoglobin to carry oxygen. This condition (anaemia) leads to tiredness, weakness, and breathlessness because cells do not receive enough oxygen for energy production.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fewer RBCs would reduce energy (not increase, A). RBCs do not affect immunity (C) or clotting (D). Reduced RBCs lead to tiredness and weakness (B) due to poor oxygen supply.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct comparison between xylem and phloem?

options.text: Xylem transports food; Phloem transports water
Xylem transports water upward; Phloem transports food in all directions

questions.explanation_correct: Xylem transports water and minerals in one direction - upward from roots to leaves. Phloem transports prepared food from leaves to other parts in all directions (upward and downward).
questions.explanation_incorrect: A reverses the roles. They do not both transport only water (C) or only food (D). Xylem carries water upward and phloem carries food in all directions (B).

questions.question_text: The two lower chambers of the heart that pump blood out are called:
questions.explanation_correct: The two lower chambers of the heart are called ventricles. The right ventricle pumps blood to the lungs and the left ventricle pumps blood to the rest of the body. Ventricles have thicker walls than atria.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atria (A) are the upper receiving chambers. Arteries (C) are blood vessels. Valves (D) prevent backflow. Ventricles (B) are the lower pumping chambers.

questions.question_text: Which of the following substances is NOT present in urine of a healthy person?
questions.explanation_correct: Glucose is not normally present in the urine of a healthy person. Healthy kidneys reabsorb all glucose back into the blood. Presence of glucose in urine (glucosuria) may indicate diabetes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Urea (A), water (B), and excess salts (D) are normal components of urine. Glucose (C) is normally reabsorbed by healthy kidneys and should not be present in urine.

questions.question_text: Which blood vessel would bleed the most if cut?
questions.explanation_correct: An artery would bleed the most because it carries blood at high pressure directly from the heart. The blood would spurt out forcefully. Veins bleed steadily and capillaries bleed very little.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Capillaries (A) are tiny and bleed minimally. Veins (B) bleed steadily at lower pressure. They do not all bleed equally (D). Arteries (C) carry blood at the highest pressure and bleed most severely.

questions.question_text: Root hairs in plants are important because they:

options.text: Transport food from leaves to roots
Increase surface area for absorption of water and minerals from soil

questions.explanation_correct: Root hairs are thin, hair-like extensions of root cells that greatly increase the surface area available for absorbing water and minerals from the soil. More surface area means more efficient absorption.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Food transport (A) is done by phloem. Root hairs do not protect from insects (C) or produce chlorophyll (D). Their main function is increasing absorption surface area (B).

questions.question_text: The process of artificial filtering of blood when kidneys fail is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Dialysis is the medical process used to filter blood artificially when a person's kidneys are not functioning properly. A dialysis machine acts as an artificial kidney, removing waste products and excess fluid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'dialysis'. It is a life-saving treatment for patients with kidney failure, where a machine performs the filtering function that healthy kidneys would normally do.
